Generate random time series dataframe

{% raw %}

generate_TS_df[source]

generate_TS_df(rows, cols)

Generates a dataframe containing a multivariate time series, where each column represents a variable and each row a time point (sample). The timestamp is in the index of the dataframe, and it is created with a even space of 1 second between samples

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df = generate_TS_df(3, 5)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_eq(df.shape, (3, 5))
{% endraw %}

pandas Dataframe utilities

Normalize columns

{% raw %}

normalize_columns[source]

normalize_columns(df:DataFrame)

Normalize columns from df to have 0 mean and 1 standard deviation

Remove constant columns

{% raw %}

remove_constant_columns[source]

remove_constant_columns(df:DataFrame)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
foo = generate_TS_df(3, 3)
foo['constant'] = [0.0]*len(foo)
foo
0 1 2 constant
2021-02-18 12:08:27.150282 0.613260 1.009989 0.841050 0.0
2021-02-18 12:08:28.150282 0.013274 0.227043 0.053924 0.0
2021-02-18 12:08:29.150282 -1.408074 0.473010 0.176688 0.0
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
bar = remove_constant_columns(foo)
bar
0 1 2
2021-02-18 12:08:27.150282 0.613260 1.009989 0.841050
2021-02-18 12:08:28.150282 0.013274 0.227043 0.053924
2021-02-18 12:08:29.150282 -1.408074 0.473010 0.176688
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
column_diff = set(foo.columns) - set(bar.columns)
test_eq_type(column_diff, set(['constant']))
{% endraw %}

Create wandb artifact containing just the reference to an object pass as argument

{% raw %}

class ReferenceArtifact[source]

ReferenceArtifact(obj, name, folder=None, description:Optional[str]=None, metadata:Optional[dict]=None) :: Artifact

Constructs an empty artifact whose contents can be populated using its add family of functions. Once the artifact has all the desired files, you can call wandb.log_artifact() to log it.

Arguments: name: (str) A human-readable name for this artifact, which is how you can identify this artifact in the UI or reference it in use_artifact calls. Names can contain letters, numbers, underscores, hyphens, and dots. The name must be unique across a project. type: (str) The type of the artifact, which is used to organize and differentiate artifacts. Common types include dataset or model, but you can use any string containing letters, numbers, underscores, hyphens, and dots. description: (str, optional) Free text that offers a description of the artifact. The description is markdown rendered in the UI, so this is a good place to place tables, links, etc. metadata: (dict, optional) Structured data associated with the artifact, for example class distribution of a dataset. This will eventually be queryable and plottable in the UI. There is a hard limit of 100 total keys.

Examples: Basic usage

```
wandb.init()

artifact = wandb.Artifact('mnist', type='dataset')
artifact.add_dir('mnist/')
wandb.log_artifact(artifact)
```

Raises: Exception: if problem.

Returns: An Artifact object.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

When a reference artifact is used by one wandb run, we should have a method to get the original object from it

{% raw %}

Artifact.to_obj[source]

Artifact.to_obj()

Download the files of a saved ReferenceArtifact and get the referenced object. The artifact must come from a call to run.use_artifact with a proper wandb run.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Test with Reference artifact from a df

{% raw %} 
foo = generate_TS_df(3, 3)
bar = ReferenceArtifact(obj=foo, name='test_reference_artifact')
bar.manifest.entries.values()

dict_values([<ManifestEntry ref: file:///home/dmontalvo/data/PACMEL-2019/wandb_artifacts/-7799705695382701625/-7799705695382701625>])
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_eq(bar.name, 'test_reference_artifact')
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_eq(bar.metadata['ref']['type'], str(type(foo)))
{% endraw %}

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_eq(bar.metadata['ref']['type'], str(type(foo)))

Keras add plot_top_losses functionality

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

Sequential.plot_top_losses[source]

Sequential.plot_top_losses(validation_data, k, largest=True, return_fig=True, title_pos=0.99, **kwargs)

Take the validation data of model self, compute the model losses for every item there, sort, and plot the results. If largest is True, the validation losses will be sorted from larger to lower. Once they are sorted, take the k first items based on this order and plot the predictions. If 'return_fig' is true, a Figure-set of plots is returned. If not, just showed on screen

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}
